articles.headline: China Announces That It Will Expel American Journalists
articles.snippet: The announcement comes weeks after President Trump limited the number of Chinese citizens who can work in the United States for five state-run Chinese news organizations.
articles.abstract: The announcement comes weeks after President Trump limited the number of Chinese citizens who can work in the United States for five state-run Chinese news organizations.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a sharp escalation of tensions between the two superpowers, China announced on Tuesday that it would expel American journalists working for The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal and The Washington Post. It also demanded that those outlets, as well as the Voice of America and Time magazine, provide the Chinese government with detailed information about their operations.
articles.byline: By Marc Tracy, Edward Wong and Lara Jakes

articles.headline: Trump Now Claims He Always Knew the Coronavirus Would Be a Pandemic
articles.snippet: The president tried to rewrite his history with advising Americans about the coronavirus. His own words prove him wrong.
articles.abstract: The president tried to rewrite his history with advising Americans about the coronavirus. His own words prove him wrong.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For weeks, President Trump has minimized the coronavirus, mocked concern about it and treated the risk from it cavalierly. On Tuesday he took to the White House lectern and made a remarkable assertion: He knew it was a pandemic all along.

articles.headline: Layoffs Are Just Starting, and the Forecasts Are Bleak
articles.snippet: Shutdowns in the U.S. retail and hospitality businesses may be an early sign of the job losses that the coronavirus outbreak will inflict on the economy.
articles.abstract: Shutdowns in the U.S. retail and hospitality businesses may be an early sign of the job losses that the coronavirus outbreak will inflict on the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Angela Gervasi was enjoying a day off on Thursday when she got a text from a co-worker: “Have you heard?”
articles.byline: By Ben Casselman, Sapna Maheshwari and David Yaffe-Bellany

articles.headline: Boeing Mirrors the Economy. It Doesn’t Look Good.
articles.snippet: The grounding of the 737 Max after two deadly crashes had already strained the company. The coronavirus is pushing it to the brink.
articles.abstract: The grounding of the 737 Max after two deadly crashes had already strained the company. The coronavirus is pushing it to the brink.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the crisis caused by the coronavirus continues to spiral out of control, the vast ramifications of the global economy’s screeching to a halt are already on display at one of most important companies in the United States: Boeing.
articles.byline: By David Gelles and Natalie Kitroeff

articles.headline: Biden Sweeps Three States and Takes Commanding Lead, as Virus Reshapes American Politics
articles.snippet: With a broad coalition, Joseph R. Biden Jr. defeated Bernie Sanders in Florida, Illinois and Arizona, in a rout that could add to pressure on Mr. Sanders to end his campaign.
articles.abstract: With a broad coalition, Joseph R. Biden Jr. defeated Bernie Sanders in Florida, Illinois and Arizona, in a rout that could add to pressure on Mr. Sanders to end his campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: Joseph R. Biden Jr. easily defeated Senator Bernie Sanders in three major primaries on Tuesday, all but extinguishing Mr. Sanders’s chances for a comeback, as anxious Americans turned out to vote amid a series of cascading disruptions from the coronavirus pandemic.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Pandemic Erodes Gig Economy Work
articles.snippet: Gig companies promoted their flexible hours as an economic lifeline for workers. In the coronavirus outbreak, it has been anything but.
articles.abstract: Gig companies promoted their flexible hours as an economic lifeline for workers. In the coronavirus outbreak, it has been anything but.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It was just after 11 a.m. last Wednesday when Jaime Maldonado, 51, pulled his rented Nissan into a lot outside San Francisco International Airport. He figured he had a long wait ahead — about two hours — before Lyft would ping him to pick up a passenger.
articles.byline: By Kate Conger, Adam Satariano and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: Bernie Sanders Has No Realistic Chance to Win. Some Democrats Say, ‘It’s Over.’
articles.snippet: With an increasingly narrow path to the nomination, Mr. Sanders and his advisers were weighing his options amid a national health crisis.
articles.abstract: With an increasingly narrow path to the nomination, Mr. Sanders and his advisers were weighing his options amid a national health crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Read more: Bernie Sanders has officially ended his 2020 presidential campaign.]
articles.byline: By Sydney Ember, Reid J. Epstein and Glenn Thrush

articles.headline: This Is the Only Way to End the Coronavirus Financial Panic
articles.snippet: Bailouts of companies or industries just cause division. The answer: a government “bridge loan” to everyone.
articles.abstract: Bailouts of companies or industries just cause division. The answer: a government “bridge loan” to everyone.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Covid-19 crisis will take time to be solved by science. The economic crisis can be solved right now.

articles.headline: There Aren’t Enough Ventilators to Cope With the Coronavirus
articles.snippet: The United States and other countries face a critical shortage of the lifesaving machines — and no easy way to lift production.
articles.abstract: The United States and other countries face a critical shortage of the lifesaving machines — and no easy way to lift production.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the United States braces for an onslaught of coronavirus cases, hospitals and governments are confronting a grim reality: There are not nearly enough lifesaving ventilator machines to go around, and there is no way to solve the problem before the disease reaches full throttle.
articles.byline: By Sarah Kliff, Adam Satariano, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Nicholas Kulish
